trans-unit.source: Configure an external Listener for AlwaysOn Availability Groups in Azure
trans-unit.target: Configure an external Listener for AlwaysOn Availability Groups in Azure

trans-unit.source: This tutorial walks you through steps of creating an AlwaysOn Availability Group Listener in Azure that is externally accessible by using the public Virtual IP address of the associated cloud service.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial walks you through steps of creating an AlwaysOn Availability Group Listener in Azure that is externally accessible by using the public Virtual IP address of the associated cloud service.

trans-unit.source: This topic shows you how to configure a listener for an AlwaysOn Availability Group that is externally accessible on the internet.
trans-unit.target: This topic shows you how to configure a listener for an AlwaysOn Availability Group that is externally accessible on the internet.

trans-unit.source: This is made possible associating the cloud service's public Virtual IP (VIP) address with the listener.
trans-unit.target: This is made possible associating the cloud service's public Virtual IP (VIP) address with the listener.

trans-unit.source: Your Availability Group can contain replicas that are on-premises only, Azure only, or span both on-premises and Azure for hybrid configurations.
trans-unit.target: Your Availability Group can contain replicas that are on-premises only, Azure only, or span both on-premises and Azure for hybrid configurations.

trans-unit.source: Azure replicas can reside within the same region or across multiple regions using multiple virtual networks (VNets).
trans-unit.target: Azure replicas can reside within the same region or across multiple regions using multiple virtual networks (VNets).

trans-unit.source: The steps below assume you have already <linkText>configured an availability group</linkText><title></title> but have not configured a listener.
trans-unit.target: The steps below assume you have already <linkText>configured an availability group</linkText><title></title> but have not configured a listener.

trans-unit.source: Note the following limitations on the availability group listener in Azure when you are deploying using the cloud service pubic VIP address:
trans-unit.target: Note the following limitations on the availability group listener in Azure when you are deploying using the cloud service pubic VIP address:

trans-unit.source: The availability group listener is supported on Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2012, and Windows Server 2012 R2.
trans-unit.target: The availability group listener is supported on Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2012, and Windows Server 2012 R2.

trans-unit.source: The client application must reside on a different cloud service than the one that contains your availability group VMs.
trans-unit.target: The client application must reside on a different cloud service than the one that contains your availability group VMs.

trans-unit.source: Azure does not support direct server return with client and server in the same cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Azure does not support direct server return with client and server in the same cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Only one availability group listener is supported per cloud service because the listener is configured to either use the cloud service VIP address.
trans-unit.target: Only one availability group listener is supported per cloud service because the listener is configured to either use the cloud service VIP address.

trans-unit.source: Note that this limitation is still in effect although Azure now supports the creation of multiple VIP addresses in a given cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Note that this limitation is still in effect although Azure now supports the creation of multiple VIP addresses in a given cloud service.

trans-unit.source: If you are creating a listener for a hybrid environment, the on-premises network must have connectivity to the public Internet in addition to the site-to-site VPN with the Azure virtual network.
trans-unit.target: If you are creating a listener for a hybrid environment, the on-premises network must have connectivity to the public Internet in addition to the site-to-site VPN with the Azure virtual network.

trans-unit.source: When in the Azure subnet, the availability group listener is reachable only by the public IP address of the respective cloud service.
trans-unit.target: When in the Azure subnet, the availability group listener is reachable only by the public IP address of the respective cloud service.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial focuses on using PowerShell to create a listener for an Availability Group that includes Azure replicas.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial focuses on using PowerShell to create a listener for an Availability Group that includes Azure replicas.

trans-unit.source: For more information on how to configure listeners using SSMS or Transact-SQL, see <linkText>Create or Configure an Availability Group Listener</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on how to configure listeners using SSMS or Transact-SQL, see <linkText>Create or Configure an Availability Group Listener</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This article focuses on creating a listener that uses external load balancing.
trans-unit.target: This article focuses on creating a listener that uses external load balancing.

trans-unit.source: If you want a listener that is private to your virtual network, see the version of this article that provides steps for setting up an <linkText>listener with ILB</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: If you want a listener that is private to your virtual network, see the version of this article that provides steps for setting up an <linkText>listener with ILB</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: External load balancing uses the virtual the public Virtual IP address of the cloud service that hosts your VMs.
trans-unit.target: External load balancing uses the virtual the public Virtual IP address of the cloud service that hosts your VMs.

trans-unit.source: So you do not need to create or configure the load balancer in this case.
trans-unit.target: So you do not need to create or configure the load balancer in this case.

trans-unit.source: Copy the PowerShell script below into a text editor and set the variable values to suit your environment (defaults have been provided for some parameters).
trans-unit.target: Copy the PowerShell script below into a text editor and set the variable values to suit your environment (defaults have been provided for some parameters).

trans-unit.source: Note that if your availability group spans Azure regions, you must run the script once in each datacenter for the cloud service and nodes that reside in that datacenter.
trans-unit.target: Note that if your availability group spans Azure regions, you must run the script once in each datacenter for the cloud service and nodes that reside in that datacenter.

trans-unit.source: Once you have set the variables, copy the script from the text editor into your Azure PowerShell session to run it.
trans-unit.target: Once you have set the variables, copy the script from the text editor into your Azure PowerShell session to run it.

trans-unit.source: If the prompt still shows >>, type ENTER again to make sure the script starts running.
trans-unit.target: If the prompt still shows >>, type ENTER again to make sure the script starts running.

trans-unit.source: For external load balancing, you must obtain the public virtual IP address of the cloud service that contains your replicas.
trans-unit.target: For external load balancing, you must obtain the public virtual IP address of the cloud service that contains your replicas.

trans-unit.source: Log into the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: Log into the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the cloud service that contains your availability group VM.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the cloud service that contains your availability group VM.

trans-unit.source: Open the Dashboard view.
trans-unit.target: Open the Dashboard view.

trans-unit.source: Note the address shown under Public Virtual IP (VIP) Address.
trans-unit.target: Note the address shown under Public Virtual IP (VIP) Address.

trans-unit.source: If your solution spans VNets, repeat this step for each cloud service that contains a VM that hosts a replica.
trans-unit.target: If your solution spans VNets, repeat this step for each cloud service that contains a VM that hosts a replica.

trans-unit.source: On one of the VMs, copy the PowerShell script below into a text editor and set the variables to the values you noted earlier.
trans-unit.target: On one of the VMs, copy the PowerShell script below into a text editor and set the variables to the values you noted earlier.

trans-unit.source: Once you have set the variables, open an elevated Windows PowerShell window, then copy the script from the text editor and paste into your Azure PowerShell session to run it.
trans-unit.target: Once you have set the variables, open an elevated Windows PowerShell window, then copy the script from the text editor and paste into your Azure PowerShell session to run it.

trans-unit.source: If the prompt still shows >>, type ENTER again to make sure the script starts running.
trans-unit.target: If the prompt still shows >>, type ENTER again to make sure the script starts running.

trans-unit.source: Repeat this on each VM.
trans-unit.target: Repeat this on each VM.

trans-unit.source: This script configures the IP Address resource with the IP address of the cloud service and sets other parameters like the probe port.
trans-unit.target: This script configures the IP Address resource with the IP address of the cloud service and sets other parameters like the probe port.

trans-unit.source: When the IP Address resource is brought online, it can then respond to the polling on the probe port from the load-balanced endpoint created earlier in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: When the IP Address resource is brought online, it can then respond to the polling on the probe port from the load-balanced endpoint created earlier in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: In order to access the listener from outside the virtual network, you must be using external/public load balancing (described in this topic) rather than ILB, which is only accesible within the same VNet.
trans-unit.target: In order to access the listener from outside the virtual network, you must be using external/public load balancing (described in this topic) rather than ILB, which is only accesible within the same VNet.

trans-unit.source: In the connection string, you specify the cloud service name.
trans-unit.target: In the connection string, you specify the cloud service name.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you had a cloud service with the name mycloudservice, the sqlcmd statement would be as follows:
trans-unit.target: For example, if you had a cloud service with the name mycloudservice, the sqlcmd statement would be as follows:

trans-unit.source: Unlike the previous example, SQL authentication must be used, because the caller cannot use windows authentication over the internet.
trans-unit.target: Unlike the previous example, SQL authentication must be used, because the caller cannot use windows authentication over the internet.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>AlwaysOn Availability Group in Azure VM: Client Connectivity Scenarios</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>AlwaysOn Availability Group in Azure VM: Client Connectivity Scenarios</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: When using SQL authentication, make sure that you create the same login on both replicas.
trans-unit.target: When using SQL authentication, make sure that you create the same login on both replicas.

trans-unit.source: For more information about troubleshooting logins with Availability Groups, see <linkText>How to map logins or use contained SQL database user to connect to other replicas and map to availability databases</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about troubleshooting logins with Availability Groups, see <linkText>How to map logins or use contained SQL database user to connect to other replicas and map to availability databases</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If the AlwaysOn replicas are in different subnets, clients must specify MultisubnetFailover=True in the connection string.
trans-unit.target: If the AlwaysOn replicas are in different subnets, clients must specify MultisubnetFailover=True in the connection string.

trans-unit.source: This results in parallel connection attempts to replicas in the different subnets.
trans-unit.target: This results in parallel connection attempts to replicas in the different subnets.

trans-unit.source: Note that this scenario includes a cross-region AlwaysOn Availability Group deployment.
trans-unit.target: Note that this scenario includes a cross-region AlwaysOn Availability Group deployment.
